skills.name: Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a number
Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers
Read a negative integer temperature from a thermometer
Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers

explanations.A: 5 intervals represents 10, that means each interval represents 2. Counting down from 0 in 2s we get down to -8.
explanations.B: I think you thought each jump (or interval) was worth 1, and went 1 above -10. But how much would each jump be if 5 jumps is worth 10?
explanations.C: I think you thought each jump (or interval) was worth 1, and went down 4 from 0. But how much would each jump be if 5 jumps is worth 10?
explanations.D: I think you thought each jump (or interval) was worth 1, and then you tried to go 1 more than -10. But how much would each jump be if 5 jumps is worth 10?

explanations.A: I think you thought each jump (or interval) was worth 1, and went down 2 jumps from 0. But how much would each jump be if 5 jumps is worth 10?
explanations.B: I think you thought each jump (or interval) was worth 1, and went 3 above -10. But how much would each jump be if 5 jumps is worth 10?
explanations.C: 5 intervals represents 10, that means each interval represents 2. Counting down from 0 in 2s we get down to -4.
explanations.D: I think you thought each jump (or interval) was worth 1, and then you tried to go 3 above -10. But how much would each jump be if 5 jumps is worth 10?

explanations.A: This is the length of the whole ruler, we are looking for the length of the pencil...
explanations.B: To find the length of the pencil we need to look at the scale of the ruler. The rubber of the pencil is at 0cm and the tip is at 12cm therefore the length of the pencil is 12cm!
explanations.C: I think you have forgotten to include part of the pencil. We want the length all the way from the end of the rubber to the tip...
explanations.D: This is the length of the part of the ruler that isn't covered by the pencil. Can you find the length of the part of the ruler that IS covered by the pencil?

explanations.A: This is the length of the part of the ruler that isn't covered by the pencil. Can you find the length of the part of the ruler that IS covered by the pencil?
explanations.B: I think you have forgotten to include part of the pencil. We want the length all the way from the end of the rubber to the tip...
explanations.C: This is the length of the whole ruler, we are looking for the length of the pencil...
explanations.D: To find the length of the pencil we need to look at the scale of the ruler. The rubber of the pencil is at 0cm and the tip is at 10cm therefore the length of the pencil is 10cm!

explanations.A: To find how much liquid is in the container we need to read the water level at the front of the container...
explanations.B: We can see from the diagram the water level lies 3 spaces above 50ml. Between 100ml and 50ml there are 5 spaces so each space is worth 10ml. This means the water level lies at 80ml
explanations.C: This would be an estimate for the total volume of the container but the question is asking how much liquid is there in the container...
explanations.D: I think you have assumed the amount of liquid is exactly halfway between 50 and 100 but look at the scale again, at what value does the water level lie?

explanations.A: We can see from the diagram the water level lies 1 space above 50ml. Between 100ml and 50ml there are 5 spaces so each space is worth 10ml. This means the water level lies at 60ml.
explanations.B: This would be an estimate for the total volume of the container but the question is asking how much liquid is there in the container...
explanations.C: To find how much liquid is in the container we need to read the water level at the front of the container...
explanations.D: I think you have assumed the amount of liquid is exactly halfway between 60 and 90 but look at the scale again, at what value does the water level lie?

explanations.A: Each space is not worth 10 mins... If we have 4 spaces between 12pm and 1pm that is 1 hour cut into 4 so how much is each space worth?
explanations.B: This is the total time on the schedule, the question wants the length of the nature documentary...
explanations.C: On the scale, each hour is split into 4 parts so is worth 15 mins. The nature documentary lasts 3 spaces so 3 x 15 = 45 mins
explanations.D: This is how long the news lasts, the question wants the length of the nature documentary...

explanations.A: This is how long the nature documentary lasts, the question wants the length of the news...
explanations.B: Each space is not worth 10 mins... If we have 4 spaces between 12pm and 1pm that is 1 hour cut into 4 so how much is each space worth?
explanations.C: On the scale, each hour is split into 4 parts so is worth 15 mins. The news lasts 1 space so 1 x 15 = 15 mins
explanations.D: This is the total time on the schedule, the question wants the length of the news...

explanations.A: The scale runs from 0 to 1kg and is split into 20 parts 1 รท 20 = 0.05 kg therefore each part is worth 50g. The arrow points to the 6th space along the scale 6 x 50 = 300 so it points to 300g.
explanations.B: Careful we are splitting 200g into 4 parts not 100g so each part is worth 200 รท 4 = ?
explanations.C: I think you have worked it out as if the scale ends at 500g but we have 1kg split into 20 parts. Work out the value of each part and then find what 6 of them would equal!
explanations.D: The arrow is pointing at the 6th dash but each dash is not worth 100g... We have 1kg split into 20 parts so how much is each part worth?

explanations.A: The arrow is pointing at the 9th dash but each dash is not worth 100g... We have 1kg split into 20 parts so how much is each part worth?
explanations.B: The scale runs from 0 to 1kg and is split into 20 parts 1 รท 20 = 0.05 kg therefore each part is worth 50g. The arrow points to the 9th space along the scale 9 x 50 = 450 so it points to 450g.
explanations.C: Careful we are splitting 200g into 4 parts not 100g so each part is worth 200 รท 4 = ?
explanations.D: I think you have worked it out as if the scale ends at 500g but we have 1kg split into 20 parts. Work out the value of each part and then find what 9 of them would equal!
